content.body: MikeSmith: done
thanks
I'll get the author-edition published in TR space along with the multipage
for next round of WDs
looking at "Proposing New Features" at the bottom of this page http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/HTML-WG/
"We value your opinion, really we do, but we're going to put a stiff tax on its expression, so that we won't have to hear it very often."
gsnedders: OK. I was hoping to get advice on which seats I should get...
AryehGregor: It's a bit of a myth that Hixie decides everything alone. Here's an example of influencing the decision process: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090212#l-27
MikeSmith: maybe the Author Edition should be called something like an Edition for Web Authors
MikeSmith: otherwise it looks like the Editor's Cut
I still have trouble deciding if I should get the Avenue Q tickets from the Stalls or the Royal Circle (the first balcony level)...
hsivonen: good point
hsivonen: changed now to "Edition for Web Authors"
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/
MikeSmith: thanks
hsivonen: btw, did you see my question yesterday about how to make the v.nu HTML5 parser usable by other Java apps from the command line?
goes to get pointer to logs
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100602#l-181
http://html4all.org/mailman/archives/list_html4all.org/2010-June/001066.html
hsivonen: surely the reason is that Hixie wrote the text instead of the Experts
zcorpan_: A mutation of NIH?
hsivonen: You are going to London?
bleh
jgraham: yes. In July.
hsivonen: Nice. Holiday?
jgraham: yeah, a short one, since I'd have a layover at LHR anyway
http://blog.chromium.org/2010/06/websocket-protocol-updated.html
I booked tickets for Avenue Q. gsnedders is effective at this social media marketing thing.
What you mean he convinced you to go without ever actually having gone himself or having any idea of product quality?
jgraham: right. very effective indeed.
haha
great to see that Chromium is tracking the spec changes for Web Socket
working with hg on a hard disk feels very slow after getting used to an SSD
http://twitter.com/mikeplate/statuses/15247455331
'"The most unreadable specification I've read in 20 years of standardization" Daniel Glazman on WhatWG #html5 doc spec #swdc'
wonders if the other specs that Daniel has read have been as precise
wonders if he has read any other specs at all
wonders if the other specs will lead to such interoperable behaviour in such a complex area
wonders how carefully he read CSS 2.1 :-P
annevk: surely you're not suggesting that the CSS 2.1 spec was unreadable! :)
I'm suggesting it is pretty hard to read
And incomplete unfortunately on certain important topics...
I can never remember where to find half the layout properties
I think my serious response would be http://dbaron.org/log/20100531-specs
someone emailed me again the other day about href on any element... gave an explanation plus pointer to the FAQ entry
easy way: you should have just pointed out that it's now fine to put whatever you want into a-elements :>
he was actually aware of that
I'm interested in understand why it isn't possible for javascript to kick off a page transition and have granular control over the request in the same as you do with XHR - anyone know?
mikekelly: because there's only one person in the world who wants to do that
hsivonen: And Hixie was good at convincing me I should go (though mainly F2F, so no IRC logs of this)
jgraham: who's marlin? did you mean malin?
zcorpan_: Probably
He's implying she's fishy
I consider it a good day if I manage to spell my own name right
jgraham, low standards much?
jgraham: Your spelling it better than mine. :P
though I guess it's a good thing it doesn't depend on externalities, like someone else spelling your name right for a change...
(There again, that is a really low standard.)
annevk: I like to use the word "realistic"
Does anyone happen to have an URL for a style sheet that's guarenteed to load artificially slowly?
hsivonen: steve souders should have that with cuzillion
hsivonen: I guess OPera internal urls aren't that useful to you ;)
hsivonen: http://stevesouders.com/cuzillion/
Rik`: Neat
Rik`: thanks
yeah, pretty useful
what's a cross-browser (incl. IE) way to ask an element for its color?
None that I know of, you have to combine getComputedStyle and currentStyle
and don't forget the please argument
brb, implementing intercal support in webkit
ok. maybe I'll try to see if Opera and WebKit support offsetHeight
You can't just detect getComputedStyle and fallback to currentStyle?
Dashiva: I just want to check if a test style sheet is applied at a given point
I don't need to check arbitrary styles.
offsetHeight should work
as I expected, none of the top 4 engines behaves like the spec says when a document.written internal script occurs right after an external style sheet in the same document.write
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/test/moz/sheet-blocking-script.html
time to file a spec bug
it took a lot of trying to come up with a test that explained the behavior of all 4
And there are _still_ people who object to the design principles, wonderful
whew. http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9843 filed.
is there a service that lets me search Hixie's commit messages?
or browse blame for the spec?
If there isn't, you could search the archives for commit-watchers
hsivonen: I assume you don't count the avaliability of svn for checkout as "a service"
jgraham: isn't it slow? and no Web UI?
needs to find the SVG URL
guesses correctly
hsivonen: Yes
OK, now I need to find the list discussion that motivated http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker?from=13&to=14
I was unable to find a public discussion leading to that change.
r14!? Man, that's old sk00l.
this manifest should hit /offline/update_all_events regardless of cache/network status right?
http://pastie.org/990656
Hmm.  <input required> in Chrome dev channel seemingly doesn't submit the form, but gives no error.
It just focuses the password field.
I mean, the required field.
AryehGregor: it's flagged as invalid on the dom node - you have to go all JS on the element
That seems like a really bad feature to deploy.  If you don't have UI, you shouldn't enforce the requirements either.
AryehGregor: completely agree
The form validation API is not meant to be JS-only.  It's meant to work even if the author provides no JS.
Are there minimal UI requirements in the spec here?
is looking
No
would hope there aren't any UI requirements
Not even "you have to tell the user and not just silently fail"?
That seems like a pretty reasonable UI requirement to me.
What if it's Googlebot?
I'm talking about browsers here.  Googlebot is not a browser.
A Googlebot does not fall into the "Web browsers and other interactive user agents" category.
It's "Data mining tools", I suppose.
So it only has to follow the semantic requirements, not UI requirements.

http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#constraint-validation "Report the problems with the constraints of at least one of the elements given in unhandled invalid controls to the user."
It explicitly suggests focusing the element, but that's just not enough.  There needs to be some text somehow.
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=34945
hmm, so <link rel=next> is being spread on twitter as being 'html5 prefetch'
http://keyboardy.com/programming/html5-link-prefetching/
Didn't it way predate -- oh, never mind, buzzword.
comments
Haha, I love <canvas>+<video> *so* much - http://betaweb.csug.rochester.edu/~jparish/public/canvas/video.html
that's awesome
I think it would be even more awesome if it didn't draw into the canvas, but just used it for calculation, and instead did the display in real text.
dhtml 4 life
somewhat unrelated, but did you see kangax's svg -> canvas parser thingy? http://yura.thinkweb2.com/canvas_demo/
No, I had not previously seen that!
Random note - anyone know who the dude in that image is?
the tongue sticking out guy?
Yeah.
ha. no clue. i can ping kangax on IM and ask though
kk.  I'm just wondering because it looks sorta like jimmy urine.
quoth the kangax, "just some svg i found on the web"
Kk.
Awesome, Ubuntu versions are now tracking latest Firefox instead of freezing on a stable branch forever.
hm
AryehGregor, link to info?
gratz|home, http://fridge.ubuntu.com/node/2051
cool
was a bit surprised since they freeze everything for standardisation / support
good to see though :D
brb
AryehGregor: You around?  Question about Hebrew numbering.
TabAtkins, I'm here.
Do you know how accurate the current css3-lists description of hebrew numbering is?  It looks like it's pretty easy to describe with a simple greedy additive algorithm.
I commented about that some time ago, didn't I?
Yeah, but I can't follow that discussion well enough to be sure.
The conclusion was that it should just stop at 999,999.
Okay, that's fine.
If you do that, then it's very simple.
And the appears if and only if the number is 1k or greater?
the geresh
Well, there are still a couple weird things, actually.
Well, plus the 15/16 exceptions.
I'd ditch all the places where it uses a Hebrew word, like 0, 1000, 2000, etc.
The current algo doesn't use a word anywhere.
Okay, what URL are you looking at?
I'm looking at a WD, I think.
http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-lists/#algorithmic
It's just "choose a value from this list for the 100k digit, 10k digit, 1k digit, add a geresh if necessary, 100 digit, 10 digit, 1 digit".
This looks fine to me, yes.
Kk, cool.
I don't know how standard it is for stuff above 1000.  I've seen that convention used, but people also sometimes just continue on without a geresh.
E.g., תתר for 1000.
I'm developing a syntax to allow authors to specify list-styles themselves.  All the non-algorithmics are trivial, and I'm trying to solve as many algorithmics as I can do simply.
That gets unwieldy above about 1200, though.
Most of them fall into either "cjk" or "additive" camps.
The Hebrew one is quite simple.  The only oddity is the 15/16 thing, I think.
Yeah, but that's easy enough to do with a greedy additive algorithm.  Just specify 19/18/17/16/15 as possible tokens.
Then it'll take those in preference to building 15/16 the "normal" way with a 10 and a 5/6.
Ah, I see.
Yeah, that should work fine.
Good to know.
Stupid ethiopic and tamil numbering systems being all complicated.
does css support roman numbers?
I can handle tamil with an addition to my additive system, but ethiopic is impossible without creating something that might as well be general purpose.
zcorpan_: CSS3 Lists describes it (under the algorithmic types).
My method of defining list-styles also supports it.
nice
I currently have an example UA stylesheet that defines every non-glyph and non-algorithmic list type.  I'll be adding the algorithmics that I can handle soon.
I wonder where I could find someone who knows the tamil numbering system?
I want to confirm something before I give up on it.
Random fun fact - in my syntax, it's pretty easy to describe a "one, two, three" list-style.
You should support Roman numerals the way the romans actually used them most of the time, with IIII instead of IV and so on.  Then it's really trivial.
(fun fact: watches with Roman numerals typically have IIII instead of IV, but IX instead of VIIII)
Indeed, both of those systems are trivial.
The subtractive roman numerals just require a handful more entries in the token list.
(So that it'll take "XC" for 90 if it can, frex.)
The only thing I can't do in my system is support overbars, but honestly who cares.
I'm fine with the range just being 1-39999.
didn't know about overbars in roman numbers
There's no Roman-numeral-with-overbar Unicode character?
characters.
I dunno.  Maybe?
I don't see it.
There are Roman numerals around U+2160 ff., but none with overbars.
At least not in my font.
Yeah, though apparently unicode recommends against using them.  Apparently they're mainly for cjk usage.
They recommend just using latin letters normally.
Right, I remember that.
Hmm, does it make sense to include the 5k and 10k characters?  They're marked as "archaic" roman numerals in the unicode listing.
I thought most Roman numerals were pretty archaic
They prefer the term "classical".
Only Roman letters are usually used for Roman numerals.
Up to M for 1000.
Today, I mean.
chrome 6.0.422.0 crashes on my websocket testsuite
hmm, one test not only killed the tab but killed all of chrome
now it seems to be any test - maybe chrome got fed up and didn't like websockets anymore
You know Chrome changed the WebSocket implementation incompatibly in 6.0, right?
assumes so, but is just checking
yes, that's why my tests work at all
i should probably look into making my tests public
seems it crashes if the server sends a binary frame with length 2^32
ok out of 158 tests, chrome passes 98 and crashes on 2, and sometimes seemingly crashes hard on any test
zcorpan_: On OS X?
yes
seems chrome happily opens the connection without checking the upgrade and connection fields
Argh, damn you hebrew.  I'm just going to skip providing the hebrew list-type in actual characters and only do it with escapes, because bidi mixing is super-frustrating.  >_<
It's super-frustrating even if you can actually read it.
Especially when it keeps switching direction as you type.
For real.  I was about to start cussing when it was swapping the direction of backspace and delete based on which direction I approached the comma from.
Yep.
